Message.Title: Analyst: Apple’s Display Future Looks Like This
Message.Msg: January 08, 2013 Topeka Capital analyst Brian White Sharp has said it’s inevitable for Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) to start using Sharp’s new IGZO technology, which was showed off by the manufacturer at the Consumer Electronics Show as the future of mobile displays. Sharp said the advanced displays had twice the resolution of a conventional LCD screen with up to 90 percent power savings. They can also continue to display an image when the power is turned off. The buzz about Apple possibly buying the new screens has been swirling for a while, with word a few months ago that it was investigating using the panels in the third-generation iPad. That, according to some reports, didn’t happen because the technology was not ready for mass production. Sharp was accompanied at the IGZO demonstration by Apple mobile display supplier Corning (NYSE:GLW). White, who attended the demonstration, wrote in a research note after the event that Apple would be the “prime candidate” to adopt IGZO for its mobile devices. While using it would help Apple compete more strongly with Samsung (SSNLF.PK), such a deal with Sharp would also reduce its reliance on LG Display (NYSE:LPL), he said. The Apple display manufacturer had struggled to meet the required standards and quantities for the iPad’s Retina display in early 2012.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Apple is working on a cheaper iPhone that could launch later this year, the WSJ reports. One source says the device could resemble the regular iPhone, but "with a different, less-expensive body." The cheapest iPhone currently sold (the 8GB iPhone 4) goes for $450 unlocked, putting it out of the reach of many emerging markets buyers, as well as some prepaid buyers in developed markets. The fact low-end Android phones sell for much less (sometimes less than $150 unlocked) has done wonders for Android's international share.

Topic.Title: Cheaper Iphone? The stupidest thing Apple will do.

Message.Msg: If they can make 40% gross margin, then, it doesn't dilute the Company margin and they grow much faster given the majority of future growth will come from emerging markets. Also, other strategic advantages. First, China Mobil already losing market share to China Telecom and China Unicom at high-end. Apple very likely to force China Mobil to play on Apple's terms if the threat of losing share at the low end exists too. Second, they won't get far in China, India or many of the fast growing emerging markets without participating at low-end. Third, if they get people on Apple at low-end, they can move them up over time to the higher end and to iPad. The key is the 40% gross margin.

Message.Title: Form 8-K for VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS INC
Message.Msg: On January 8, 2013, in connection with the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Dan Mead, President and CEO of Verizon Wireless gave an update on Verizon Wireless's ("Verizon") fourth quarter 2012 performance. Verizon expects 2.1 million retail postpaid net additions, total smartphone activations of 9.8 million with a higher mix of Apple smartphones, and stronger indirect channel performance in the fourth quarter of 2012. This will result in fourth quarter 2012 segment EBITDA service margin to be slightly lower than that of fourth quarter 2011.

Topic.Title: Incredible Apple stuck in $515s - $530s, right before earnings

Message.Msg: Still think we will see some upward movement into earnings as the data points suggest a strong quarter. And, if they deliver more like 38% or 39% gross margins this period rather than their 36% guide it will help immensely, as it appears analysts are counting on that range this quarter and getting back above 40% for the year. Given where they are on the cost curve for the vast majority of products this quarter, they should have no problem delivering 41% to 43% gross margin for the year, if they can start from 38% to 39% this period, even though their iPhone mix will be its best this quarter most likely as iPad growth leads.

Topic.Title: Cheaper Iphone? The stupidest thing Apple will do.

Message.Msg: The cheaper lighter iPhone would only be for China customers... The Chinese are poor and cant afford to pay the premium price of the iPhone we pay here in the states. This plan is brilliant because if Apple can succeed in putting an iPhone in every Chinese persons hands no matter the price it would add up to billions and take away from Samsung and others. These phones would run off China Mobile and the other China carriers. Think of it as the dollar stores or Walmart... They sell more quantity and lower prices which over the long run add up to the same or more in sales of retailers such as Target or Macys. Samsung has been doing it for years and all the so called experts think its working out for Samsung. I agree that Samsung is even selling phones simply because of the outrages price drops they offer customers. They are basically giving the phones away.

Message.Title: T MOBILE IS ALREADY CRANKING iPHONE SALES
Message.Msg: THEIR "OFFICIAL" LAUNCH IS THIS MONTH, BUT THEY ALREADY HAVE MORE THAN 2M iPHONES ACTIVATED. SO APPLE IS GOING TO SAVE THEM AND SPRINT! Tuesday, January 08, 2013, 04:34 pm Unofficial U.S. carrier T-Mobile has 2M iPhones on network, over 100K new activations a month Despite not being an official Apple partner carrier, T-Mobile on Tuesday announced that it has nearly 2 million iPhones operating on its network, and interest in Apple's handset is fueling over 100,000 activations every month. In statements at the Citi Global Internet, Media and Telecommunications conference, T-Mobile CEO John Legere told attendees that some 1.9 million iPhones have been activated as of January, which TmoNews reports is a boost of 200,000 users in the past 30 days alone. While it is the fourth-largest wireless carrier in the U.S., T-Mobile only recently announced a deal to sell Apple's products starting in 2013. In contrast, small regional carriers like Appalachian Wireless and Cricket Communications kicked off sales of the latest iPhone 5 in September. T-Mobile has apparently changed its tune in regard to the iPhone as the company's U.S. Chief Operating Officer Jim Ailing said in November that he was unwilling to make the major investment required to carry Apple's popular handset. "Make no mistake about it: We would love to carry the iPhone," Ailing said at the time. "However, we want the economies to be right for us." The economics have apparently changed over the past month and T-Mobile seems to be raring to start official sales later this year. T-Mobile’s Chief Technology Officer Neville Ray said in a statement earlier today that the company's first LTE market is slated to roll out in Las Vegas over the next “two to three weeks.”

Message.Title: NANSEN Investments take on Less Expensive Iphone
Message.Msg: Tim Cook is in China today meeting with Miao Wei, China’s head of the Ministery of Industry and Information Technology. The number one issue is when will the Chinese government, which has a controlling interest in China Mobile, agree to a deal between Apple and China Mobile. I fully expect Tim Cook to have a secret meeting with Li Yue, China Mobile’s President after his meeting with government officials. Is Tim Cook going to announce the long awaited agreement between Apple and China Mobile? I think there is a good chance an announcement may be imminent. I would put the odds at about 50/50. China Mobile has 700 MM subscribers. Apple’s 2 Chinese telecom partners in China are China Telecom with 152 MM subscribers and China Unicom with 230 MM subscribers. China Telecomm and China Unicom have been doing better than China Mobile lately because of their ability to sell the new iphone 5. China Mobile and the Chinese government have been driving a hard bargain with Apple over the amount of subsidies China Mobile has been willing to pay Apple. The Chinese government and Apple are the world’s 2 hardest bargainers. No wondor a deal has not been easy. It’s all about money. China Mobile and Apple really need each other. China Mobile is losing momentum with China Telecom and China Unicom. The Chinese government is also aware Apple is one of it’s biggest employers and feels the pressure to continue to cooperate with Apple. On the other side, Apple needs China Mobile’s 700 MM subscribers if it is going to continue expanding in China. Apple needs China to be it’s growth vehicle for the next 10 years. The United States which just passed 50% smart phone penetration will slow it’s iphone growth down when it reaches 85% smartphone adoption. On my recent 5 week trip to Asia and China I commented on the need for Apple to address the lower and middle 200-300 million smartphone market that is just developing in China and Asia. The average iphone in China is $725 and the average Android phone is $223. Samsung and Android own this market with about 90% penetration. The rumors and reports continue to mount that Apple is adressing this need with a cheap introductory iphone with larger screens. I hope that Apple can bring these introductory models to market as soon as possible. Please do not judge this decison unless you have traveled extensively through Asia. China and Asia are the future of Apple. With China, Apple can continue to grow 40% a year for the next 10 years. Without China, Apple’s 40% growth will end in 2015.

Message.Title: only a little bad news today , that's all
Message.Msg: Buyers of Apple's (AAPL) Larger iMac Will See Longer Wait Times Click here to find out more! January 9, 2013 8:47 AM EST Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) is delaying the larger version of its 27-inch iMac as manufacturing difficulties persist. According to Tom's Hardware, shipments of Apple's latest-and-greatest all-in-one desktop will ship in three to four weeks. The larger iMac was available for preorder on November 30th and CEO Tim Cook announced during the company's quarterly call that supply would be "significantly constrained." Ship times were originally two to three weeks on the large iMac. The smaller 21.5-inch iMac shows a more reasonable seven to 10 day ship time.

Message.Title: Cheaper Iphone Will Boost Margins - READ
Message.Msg: AAPL has repeatedly proven that it can command extremely high margins on inexpensive products. Take a look at the following break down from iSuppli on the Shuffle - a product that retailed for $80 but only cost AAPL $21.77 in components. Can you imagine boosting margins, tapping into much larger addressable market, and destroying Samsung in one fell swoop. Tim Cook is the man. iSuppli, a company that deconstructs gadgets to evaluate their components’ value, estimates that altogether, the Shuffle costs Apple $21.77 with components, headphones and packaging accounted for. That’s about 28 percent of the Shuffle’s $80 price tag.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: A Q1 FY13's $62.44B would result in an increase of $19.42B over a 13 week comparable $43.02B FY12. That is a YOY increase of 45.1%. If you use the full 14 week sales figures of Q1 FY12 ($46.33B), that would be an increase of $16.11B or 34.7% YOY growth.

Message.Title: Apple's High End Ipad Lost Market Share To Apple's Ipad Mini, Sales Should Be Bleak.
Message.Msg: Times have changed, Only a few would pay $1,000 for a 9.7 inch Ipad when they can buy many high end tablets with 10.1 inch screens for $500. The Ipad Mini is now the leader in Apple sales by killing the market for Apple's full sized Ipad. The worst thing a company can do is to make products that compete with their own higher end products. Now there is talk of an Iphone Mini, this will surely cut into Iphone sales, Tim Cook should be looking for a new job soon.

Message.Title: Lower-Priced iPhone is a Good Thing or it Won't Happen
Message.Msg: You can bet the management team knows that they must not materially degrade margins to launch a lower-priced iPhone. They know whatever the price, the cost must support 40% gross margin. They may be a little less because they can use the increased volume on certain parts to reduce costs on other products as well as increase iTunes and Apps activity, but you can bet they won't launch this thing if it doesn't overall contribute about 40% gross margins.

Topic.Title: cheaper iphone will capture bigger market. Not everyone can afford the iphone.this is a good thing.

Message.Msg: Exactly. Android phones under 100 bucks LITTER the market. Besides, the PLANS are what kill the smartphone market, not the phone price. The iPhone 5 can be had for 150 at Walmart. If someone isn't buying the iPhone 5 at this price, then they are not able to own the smart phone. This applies to the US Market. In the international market, the iPhone is very expensive off contract, but the difference in price off contract between every phone and the iphone is about 200 bucks. The Nexus 4 is the exception. Perhaps, Apple is trying to compete off contract with a phone price in the 500 dollar range. The phone will not be received well if they have to cheapen it this much....

Message.Title: 8,800 Billionaires in Beijing, over 7,500 Billionaires in Shangai. China's wealth rolling again
Message.Msg: The upward mobilty of China's middle class and the additional purchase power that will be created as the Chinese economy adds steam, like it is, will go down in the history books. Apple is a status symbol to many in China, and elsewhere. Guess what Apple's growth is going to look like next quarter in China alone? Visit Beijing, Honk Kong, or Shangai and you will understand how China is reported to become the most powerful economy, have the strongest military,and have the most powerful political clout over any nation in the world in 18 short years. In 5 years Apple will sell more products in China than they do currently worldwide. I'm thinking this may be good for Apple.

Message.Title: Penetrating Deeper Markets Including China
Message.Msg: Following a report by Digitimes this morning citing industry sources, The Wall St. Journal is today confirming that it, too, hears that Apple is working on a low-cost version of the iPhone, which could launch as early as this year. The phone could be made cheaper by using less expensive parts, the WSJ says. For example, it could use a different shell made of polycarbonate plastic, or parts recycled from older iPhone models. This isn’t the first time the WSJ has reported that Apple was exploring such a device – in 2011, it issued a similar report, again citing the ever-present “people familiar with the matter” as sources. Such a device would be ideal in targeting developing markets, including China, where the iPhone’s high price is a concern. According to the WSJ report, Apple has been developing this cheaper iPhone for years, but could not decide how to move forward with the device. If the report of the newer, cheaper iPhone is true, such a launch would position Apple to better compete with Android smartphones in emerging regions, where the move to smartphones is still a battle to be won. Android currently has the advantage, thanks to the variety of devices that can run the Android operating system, including those that come closer to matching the price point of the “feature phones” that users in these areas are upgrading from. As mobile analytics provider Flurry noted a year ago, the largest addressable markets for mobile apps in 2012 included India, China, and Japan, among others. China in particular saw quick gains in 2012, with the country having climbed into the No. 2 spot in terms of new iOS and Android activations as of March. China is now Apple’s second-largest market, but iPhone sales are losing traction to competition from Samsung and Nokia, plus domestic handset makers like Huawei, ZTE, and Lenovo. That being said, sales of the iPhone 5′s launch in China were reportedly strong, despite reports about the lack of lineups for the device. Apple later said it sold over 2 million units the first weekend. According to the Digitimes report, the low-cost iPhone would have a larger screen than the iPhone 5, which doesn’t sound right – that would be costly. Digitimes, however, is more hit-or-miss in terms of its reporting. The WSJ, on the other hand, gives the rumor more credence. Analysts have also said they believed Apple would have to launch such a device in order to reach the millions of users who couldn’t afford the current iPhone.

Topic.Title: When will the selling stop

Message.Msg: More like 3 months since an all time high. This is a big boys game. When in doubt study the fundamentals and remember why you bought the stock. If there is little change that you can see then hold. IMHO the smartphone market is getting bigger faster than Samdung is taking mkt share. And the new low priced iPhone will penetrate the ghettos, trailer parks and China. That's a good thing. The guy driving the Bentley in Oak Brook or Bel Air will still be going premium. We're just shoring up the low end that accounts for Samdungs mkt share. We're taking the fight down to them using their cheap materials to make a better phone w/an iPhone logo. Things are rocky but we're in good hands.

Topic.Title: ONE very basic question??

Message.Msg: They are scared of price which may go down even more if there is a miss in some aspect in the upcoming earning release. It may not be the earning itself but in margin and future guidance. Margin is expected to be lower but no one knows how low it may get. Remember, most traders aren't gamblers. Traders want to make trades with high probability of making money. If they aren't sure, they will rather get out and use the capital to trade something else they are more certain. AAPL isn't the only stock in the market.

Message.Title: VZ, VOD activation up over 20% Y/Y
Message.Msg: Verizon Wireless (VZ, VOD) says it expect to report 9.8M smartphone activations, "with a higher mix of Apple smartphones," for Q4. That figure is up 29% from the 7.7M smartphones activated a year ago, and 44% from the 6.8M activated in Q3. Verizon's Y/Y smartphone growth rate is easily above that of AT&T (T - previous), which is more iPhone-dependent, but its Q/Q rate is slower. The smartphone sales, together with strong indirect channel growth, will lead to a slight Y/Y drop in EBITDA service margin. VZ -0.5%. AAPL -0.7%. (CEO remarks: I, II)

Message.Title: Apple To Crush Numbers
Message.Msg: The initial numbers are trickling in and they're staggering, at least domestically. The fact that AT&T and Verizon have reported such strong iPhone numbers is an absolutely fantastic sign, considering Walmart's deep and unprecedented discounts. For AT&T and Verizon to face those Walmart headwinds and *still* report record sales is a sign of incredible domestic sales. If Apple is able to meet or *slightly* exceed the forecasts outside of the United States, you're looking at about 58 million iPhones sold. If they surprise a bit, and sales in China and the rest of Asia were strong, you're looking at about 62 million iPhones sold. I'm going to fall right in the middle and say that they sold 60 million iPhones. Look for earnings in the very, very high "teens." The only thing that stopped Apple from a $20 quarter was iPad mini and the larger iMac production issues. With China Mobile on board around the 3rd or 4th quarter of next year, Apple's Christmas quarter in 2013 will undoubtedly surpass the $20 mark. That, folks, is a near certainty.

Topic.Title: Option Play for Earnings

Message.Msg: Ask yourself how much money you expect to make and then realize there is an associated risk and a very real risk that if you are setting yourself up to make a lot, you are also setting yourself up to lose a lot (everything you put into the play) Seen a few guys do this and just get destroyed, one strong down day can crush your position given we are so close to expiry in Feb and there is NO GUARUNTEE appl corrects by that time. Much better off owning and holding the stock. But if you must do options, ask yourself why you need to make quick buck and answer with what happens to 99% of those schemes, and then if you still must buy options then the earliest expiration you should consider is Jan 14, preferably Jan 15. By then appl will certainly have china and this dip will be seen for the buying oppurtunity it is. We could very well be deep into 2013 with apple trading low 500's.... if you can't figure that scenario (macro concerns in addition to aapl concerns) then you should not be playing options.

Message.Title: The "Cheap" Phone is Good Myth
Message.Msg: Apple made its "bones" - created huge quarters in sales and earning by selling their nproducts at significantly higher prices than their competitors. That created substsantisally higher profit margins.Do you really think that that is continuing to continue by selling a "cheap" product.ie. phone? One of the concerns that has been building is the concern regarding margins. That concern now has a basis in fact. Cheaper translates into lower,and perhaps much lower margins and subsequently earnings. Do you really think that the pro believe the 8x or 10x P.E. thesis? Why not? Because they know where management is taking this company and that is to lower margin products.And ;lower earning's growth it. It simple arithmatic - not even math. The longs continued dismissal of anything that disputes their manical loyalty is killing them. And anyone who disputes THAT only has to check their monthly statement. That's fact.

Topic.Title: Option Play for Earnings

Message.Msg: Are you ok financially if those 50 contracts are worth zero come feb? Trade those into Feb 500's or 525's and then figure the payout for aapl at 550, 575, 600, 625, 650, 675, 700 and then figure out likelyhood of trading at 625+ from here. Then ask yourself what the same money does invested in shares instead of options at those price points. The big money doesn't sell these options for nothing, they can crush you in a number of ways and one of the best ways is kill your premium by driving down implied volitity where you find that stock is up 10$ and your option value stayed same or possibly went negative. OTM optoins are VERY risky bets. I hope you really get that those Feb 600's are much more likely to expire at zero than be worth even a dollar.

Message.Title: CHEAP I PHONE IS A SOLUTION
Message.Msg: A cheaper I Phone is a solution to gain access to millions of new customers at China Mobile, and for millions of young people who won't pay for an expesnive model, and thus buy cheap Samsung phones. So, is more sizes and colors. AAPL has a better brand name, and providing a less expensive model for those that want one is not going to hurt them. The presumption of canibalism and lower profit margins is really simplistic and short sighted. They may well make higher profit margins, as people will still pay more for AAPL, and obviously the cost will go down. How can you praise Samsung for its wide product breadth in one breath, and then rain on AAPL's parade when they want to expand theirs in the next?? Insane stupidity.

Message.Msg: There product quality is over hype. Their flagship products were released months ahead of apple, all these LTE person jumped on the band wagon and are locked in next 2 yrs. And I support with my case: (a) my family circle has one Galaxy S2, two Galaxy S3, one Galaxy Note II, 2 iphone 4s, one iphone 5. (b) Both S3 screen cracked and it costed $200+ to repair them, Note II has chip problem and Samsung replace the whole mother board, free. (c) one iphone 4s has intermittent WiFi problem, fixed free. With all these devices, I truely believe that Samsung will fail overtime with them pushing out low quality controlled products. Because they beat apple to the market by timing (sure they are a hardware company), they are selling more. Give Apple 2 more quarters, you will start to see the reversal. imo

Topic.Title: Option Play for Earnings

Message.Msg: Honestly, I think it is too late now to try to roll to a different strike price. 500s are selling at 10:1 the 600s price. So, I could swap my 50 600s for 5 500s. Then what? By my math, Apple needs to crawl back to 550-560 for me to be even either way. With the current sentiment, if earnings miss then we will probably go below 500 or pretty close and then even the 500s are worthless. However, if we hit earnings... and go 600+ then I want my 50 600s vs the 5 500s. Let's say Apple tops at 630 after earnings: I estimate that 500s would be worth $160-170 I estimate that 600s would be worth $60-70 That means that 5 500 options would be worth $80-85k However, 50 600 options would be worth $300-350k Am I okay with being at $0 if I am wrong? Who is. However, the upside is too compelleing to back down to a lower strike price now.

Message.Title: Apple's $50 EPS is actually $63/share. Funny that 99% investors don't even know this
Message.Msg: It is so funny how little pro's and retail understand. People are looking at apple making $50 or so in EPS for '13 assuming no upside of course. In reality that $50 is really $63. Because 99% of investors and pro fund managers do not read company reports they have no idea about this. Why you ask (and I'm sure you do since 99% of the people short and long on this board don't know)? 80% of Apple's profits are offshore. On $50 that is $40/share of their profits outside the USA. Apple holds back 35% of these earnings for repatriation of US taxes. However since that money is NEVER coming back until a repatriation holiday this is just apple being conservative in their accounting to avoid restatement down the road if the gov't goes nuts and wants to back tax every company (unlikely but hey). So if you know these dollars are never going to be taxed they add to the EPS reported. In this case another $13/share. Total earnings for '13 with no upside is $63. That puts the ex-cash multiple after taking out $130 net cash per share to around just a little over 6 times. This is a 16% earnings yield. Fewer than one quarter of 1% of all S&P co's have this earnings yield Apple will be a stock funds are piling into the first half of the year in desperation to keep up with each others and the indexes performance. Recently they dumped it to do the same which is their short term game. Have fun boys

Topic.Title: Why Do #$%$ Short NOK and RIMM When It's Apple Losing Market Share? NOK & RIMM Will Regain Their Loss

Message.Msg: I agree in principle. However, as of the last 3 days, the stock has entered a consolidation channel. Bottom is around 501 and upper band is 555. This implies to me that all the negative hype that has driven the downturn is running out of steam. The run to 705 was driven on hype but the maps mess and the Oct earnings debacle gave the ball to the short sellers and those seeking to shake out the average investors. Although the bottom has been around 501 for a month or so the formation of the consolidation channel means the ball is getting passed to APPL's CEO and he better not come up short on any points. The next highest "lower price channel" was around 522 and we need to say near or above that through this consolidation. Apart from all the noise in the price volitility, the MACD Signal is improving and the Williams A/D lows are all higher than the previous. Just based on fundamentals and ironing out the growth path to remove the spikes from overhype, I still see a conservative value at 640 today. It is now up to Appl management not to screw this one up. If they miss step at all and it falls below 501, the next stop is around 486 or so and it will be a very ugly scene. I would like to hear what others think unless you just want to slam my honest opinion. I am long.

Message.Title: WSJ once again claims Apple working on less-expensive iPhone, this time for late 2013
Message.Msg: A new Wall Street Journal report claimed Apple is working on a less-expensive iPhone that should début by late 2013. The report, which cited “people briefed on the matter,” asserted that Apple has explored such a device for years, and even the Wall Street Journal has made very similar claims over the years, but the plan has apparently now advanced. A less expensive version of the flagship device could launch later this year: The cheaper phone could resemble the standard iPhone, with a different, less-expensive body, one of the people said. One possibility Apple has considered is lowering the cost of the device by using a different shell made of polycarbonate plastic. Many other parts could remain the same or be recycled from older iPhone models. The Wall Street Journal said Apple could still drop the idea, but the Cupertino, Calif.-based company has mulled a less-expensive version and drafted a plan since at least 2009 to “grab market share and hook people on the brand.” Apple even developed designs in mid-2010 that resembled the iPhone 5 with a more price-effective back, the report said, but the company decided to discount older iPhone models instead of developing a new product. Follow Me on Twitter! @AAPLBatman Here to bring justice back to the world's most valuable company. I only post insightful AAPL news.

Message.Title: Wow... There are analysts out there more bearish on AAPL than me.....$270-$360
Message.Msg: The technical price target on Apple stock is derived from calculating a typical bull market retracement range of 38% to 61%. This gives Apple a long term technical buy point of $270-$360. At $360, Apple will be just over 3 times its tangible book value, which currently stands at $120.37/share, a good, conservative entry point for a long investor. Apple's last 2 cyclical declines were 83% off of its highs in 2002 (with bad fundamentals underlying it), 61% off of its 2007 highs (with rapidly growing fundamentals and expanding sales). We should expect a similar cyclical correction this time around. To reach the minimum retracement target of $360, Apple will experience a decline of just under 50% off of it's $705 all-time highs. To reach $270, the decline will be 62%, which is well within historical norms.

Message.Title: Apple Is The Ultimate Short
Message.Msg: You know what they say? Buy on Rumor, Sell on News. Same goes for reverse.... Short on BAD rumor, buy back on news. Why the hell would Apple put out a cheap phone? The #1 thing Apple has going for it is that it is a "novelty" and a "luxury." People do not buy Porsche and Ferrari because they have heated seats. They buy for novelty. Like it or not they are status symbols. A symbol that a person has the best... If you see someone with a phone that has an Apple on the back you know they have the BEST OF THE BEST. Now Apple will try to tamper with this recipe that took so many years to build? Unbelievable... If Apple starts putting out budget products their novelty will wear off quicker than an old farts #$%$. It amazes me that their management has no concept of why their products sell. Short this POS. Apple died when Steve Jobs died.

Not getting bearish but rather suggesting that there is a very good likelyhood of a sharp downside correction from here over the next several days. Hence, don't be suprised. Message.Title: Can't go wrong buying AAPL - News Just Out on Motley
Message.Msg: Here is the article - Despite this increased competition, Apple is still the leader of the pack when it comes to innovation (Apple TV, iPad Mini, Apple Radio, iPhone 5) and it has an unbelievably faithful following. Its Apple stores crush all other retailers in terms of sales per square foot and the company is sitting on a heap of $121 billion in cash with the ability to generate about $40 billion in free cash each year. With the company valued at just nine times forward earnings and with a projected five-year growth rate of 20.7%, I'm not exactly sure how you can go wrong buying Apple.

Message.Title: UPGRADE
Message.Msg: Shares of Apple Inc. were upgraded on Wednesday from a "Buy" to a "Strong Buy" by analyst Tim Jensen. The analyst told clients that Apple's fundamentals haven't changed, and that the recent decline of the stock a compelling value. “We think AAPL will benefit from a number of recent product refreshes, including its key iPhone and iPad offerings," Mr. Jensen wrote. "We also think the new iPad Mini will contribute to share gains. We acknowledge some slip-ups and management changes of late, but see the fundamental story as intact." The analyst also told his clients that he believes Apple could use more of its $121 billion in cash for dividends and a stock buyback. Apple is currently paying a $2.65 per share dividend and is already executing a $10 billion stock buyback program. In addition to upgrading AAPL to a "Strong Buy," Mr. Jensen raised his $700 price target to $750 for the company's stock.

Message.Title: To everyone blaming Cook for this mess
Message.Msg: Remember it was Jobs who wanted to be proprietary. His only competition was Microsoft and then Rimm. Those were easy targets. Could Cook be the victim of Jobs proprietary mindset? If Jobs were alive today, wouldn't things be as they are now with Jobs getting blasted instead of Cooks. Not to sound callous, but Jobs departed the scene just in time to keep his legacy intact and leave Cook alone in the kitchen so to speak.

Topic.Title: ugh.... that hurt

Message.Msg: The real funds are waiting to see the earnings and what the new plan is (guidance). A lower cost phone is not a bad plan, expanding iOS will result in future dollars. The challenge is this.....mobile is the only growing consumer electronics space so everyone and their dog is chasing it. It's pretty similar to when the modern GUI came to computers. Apple was first, stock went crazy, the industry followed but apple did not react until it was too late. Apple has the money to do a lot of things. What are those things, what will that mean to the business, will they be successful in those things? They need new adds, new product offerings, new partnerships, ....Smart money is waiting on the plan, it is foolish to assume the world will stay the same. It never does. If you think they will rise to the challenge, then stay long and stop worrying about it. If you think they won't rise to the challenge, get out. It's not Samsung but the next wave of phone makers that will keep adding features and dropping the price. What is the plan?

Message.Title: The Big What If ..
Message.Msg: All the frustrated,desperate beyond desperate longs are on here exclaiming how the big blow out quarter is coming. But,does this stock act like a much better than expected quarter is coming? What? Noooooobody knows how the quarter looks. It is under such steady unrelenting distribution by the institutions that it certainly seems like someone knows something.Or strongly feels they do. The pro sell it off - let it settle and lift then sell it again. And have utilized this strategy since September 21st. That a chart fact. Or is there trouble in paradise in other areas. ie. China - supply - product development? Management's silence aaaaal the way down is deafening. Cook's interview with Brian Williams was construed by many as very disturbing. He was perceived as out of his league.Forget the fact that he is no Jobs,that's a given Few are. This stock acts worse and worse.Even as the report date approaches. And,if THAT report comes in "light"? Well then at least the longs will for once and for all be put finally out of their misery. Alot of really big "if's" seem to be in place. The longs here continue to dismiss them. Not good.

Message.Title: Behind the China Door!
Message.Msg: Its not about profit margin you make on one smartphone, its about increasing your total profit margin contribution to the bottom-line. Apple clearly sees this and is now moving to this market strategy. By creating a lower priced iphone, Apple will rapidly gain market share and increase their total profit contribution. Soooooo, Mr Cook is in China for a purpose. After continued loss of market share that will continue unless the iphone is added to their product line, China Mobile is ready to get serious about a deal. Sales of the lower priced iphone and agreement with CM, Apple growth and profit picture look very, very briight. What I see happening now is many investors bought on the margin and have been scared by the Apple bashers to see. CNBC is the worst financial provider of news that I have ever seen. They should be removed from the air. I am long on Apple and plan to stay with Mr. Cook. I don't mind the shorts in this game, but truely hate those who lie and mislead the average small investor just to make a buck. Might as well sell your mother for the highest bidder if money is all that matters in your life.

Message.Title: When value wants to Boogie and wants risk wants to do the Stroll, Wisdom may well sit out the dance
Message.Msg: We can't explain AAPL action. Bashers say it has less value and more risk and pumpers say the value reward will crush the risk averse. I believe "Apple" is the Mercedes of the industry but lately "AAPL" has been the American Motors (notably the Pacer - pun intended). So what do we do? A trading friend today made $6K on 135 CC (this week, 5.20) buying at $5.30 at 1:33 and selling at $5.80 at 1:44. Those contracts closed at $3.50 and will probably open tomorrow at $2.80. So he's a trading guru. I'm not. Given the intrigue, Wisdom suggests to wait for earnings. That will be the tie-breaker for me. I'll be the wallflower who will miss the huge gap, up or down (I'm thinking it's likely huge one or the other - regardless of the news). Of course regardless of the outcome, the losing side will explain away best it can why we can't believe what we just saw. And the winning side will strut the sidelines, dancing a Jig, beating their chests and bumping their fists. But Wisdom knows better than to try to guess not only the outcome, but this market's reaction to it. So I am sitting out this dance, at least until I'm as smart as my friend. On second thought, I may just fill my dance card with Wisdom, assuming she's not already booked for the duration. GLTA

Message.Title: Goog controls 75% to Apple 14.99% of smart phones, & you wonder why Apple falling?
Message.Msg: Here are IDC's top operating systems based on worldwide smartphone unit sales and market share in the third quarter of 2012. Figures for the fourth quarter have not yet been released. — Android (Google Inc.) — 136 million units, 75 percent share (57.5 percent a year earlier) — iOS (Apple Inc.'s iPhone) — 26.9 million units, 14.9 percent share (13.8 percent a year earlier) — BlackBerry (Research in Motion Ltd.) — 7.7 million units, 4.3 percent share (9.5 percent a year earlier) — Symbian (mostly used by Nokia Corp.) — 4.1 million units, 2.3 percent share (14.6 percent a year earlier) — Windows (Microsoft Corp.) — 3.6 million units, 2 percent share (1.2 percent a year earlier) — Linux — 2.8 million units, 1.5 percent share (3.3 percent a year earlier) ,,

Message.Msg: Play the weekly's with an emphasis on friday expiration. On average, about $50 million is traded on the AAPL weekly option expiration. If you play the right side, get in the money, and close the position before markets close, a gain of 50-100% is not uncommon. I have been doing it for about a year, and I feel that it is the most lucrative, fantastic part of the market with the potential for great returns without risking too much capital. I only risk $1000, trade the open and the close. I like AAPL as a company, but I want to make money in the markets when it goes up and down. Side with the computer moving the market and close before the

Message.Msg: He knows he ultimately controls where the stock price is going. He and Oppenheimer have a lot of latitude under GAAP to show what ever number they want on the 23rd. Message.Title: DOUG KASS IS MY FAVORITE ANALYST. HE IS A REAL MAN
Message.Msg: NOT LIKE ANDY ZAKY WHO SAID Today, Apple has reached one of those very rare buy points. However, unlike our previous five recommendations, we do not necessarily believe that Apple has bottomed right here at $630 a share. We just believe that Apple won’t see much lower prices from here thereby making this a unique buying opportunity. It’s better to buy at $630 and accept a small potential drawdown than to miss the entire move. We do not believe Apple will see levels below $615 a share. Thus, anything between $615 and $630 is an extraordinary buying opportunity. Between $630 and $650, you have a great entry level.

Message.Title: Fitch likes Iphone for emerging markets and sees gains over Samsung
Message.Msg: In this context, Fitch believes the media reports of Apple's low-end iPhone make sense, particularly if Apple aspires to take a reasonable market share in major emerging markets including China and India. Samsung's operating margins improved in 2012, but Fitch expects intensified competition among the major smartphone manufactures to limit the extent of such improvement in 2013. Moreover, if Apple does release a low-end iPhone, then not only are its operating margins likely to narrow, but this could also pull down the margins for Samsung and other smartphone manufacturers in 2014

Message.Title: 10:1 SPLIT
Message.Msg: Apple management should consider splitting the stock 10:1. In doing so, they would allow their company to be trusted again by investors the same way they expect to be trusted by consumers of their products. Here's why. As a result of the high share price, Apple's is completely controlled and manipulated by the options market, particularly weekly options. A lower share price would allow more retail investors to buy even lots of common shares. The options market would have much less of an impact. Investor confidence would be restored. The stock has not split since Feb. 2005. Time to make some changes.

Message.Msg: Everyone expects Samung to extend its lead over Apple in 2013. Samsung has a wider variety of handsets in terms of both price and screen size. It also commands a greater geographical exposure, particularly in emerging markets where pre-paid plans are the norm and many people cannot afford high-end phones. Thirdly, Samsung's status as the undisputed leader for several key smartphone components - including display, processor and memory chip technologies - reinforces the likelihood that its future smartphone models will be equipped with cutting-edge technology. For example, Samsung's pending transition to smartphones with unbreakable and flexible AMOLED screens is one important development likely in 2013.

Message.Title: Median estimate 49.5 million
Message.Msg: The analysts' forecasts range from 43 million to 63 million. Median estimate: 49.5 million Click to enlarge. Chart: PED. FORTUNE (Luang Prabang, Laos) -- A year ago, Apple (AAPL) blew past all expectations by reporting sales of 37 million iPhones in the Christmas quarter, 128% more than the year before and a cool 10 million units better than the median analyst's estimate. That's what analysts call a tough compare. Nobody expects a repeat of that kind of surprise in two weeks when the company reports its first quarter earnings for fiscal 2013. Breakneck growth like that just can't go on forever -- especially with Samsung flooding the market with cheaper knock-off Androids. Also, Q1 2012 had an extra week -- 14 rather than the usual 13 -- a fact I fully expect many reporters to forget when they do their year-over-year growth calculations this time around. Still, as the two tall bars in the chart above suggest, the 57 analysts we've heard from so far -- 33 professionals and 24 independents -- expect that Apple managed to ship a ton of iPhones in the quarter that ended Dec. 29. The high estimate of 63 million -- from congenitally bullish independent Nicolae Mihalache -- represents 84% growth year over year (adjusted for the short quarter). Topeka Capital's Brian White, despite his Street-high $1,111 price target, has come in with the lowest estimate of all: 43 million, up only 26% (adjusted) above last year. You're probably safer betting on a number closer to the median: 49.5 million, up 45% from last year (or 34% if you ignore the extra week). We'll find out which of our analysts was closest to the mark when Apple reports its earnings after the markets close on Wednesday Jan. 23. I'll be on an island in the Gulf of Thailand that day, but will file my Earnings Smackdown report as soon as I get back to dry land.

Topic.Title: Why can't this stock gain traction?

Message.Msg: My opinion is that the big money hedgies and MMs have seen the numbers from VZ from T, from China (2mm iPhones in 3 days)...they know that AAPL will blow out the quarter and this will likely be a catalyst for a breakout to the upside. A company with Apple's fundamentals and balance sheet metrics, growing nicely (off of a huge revenue base i.e, law of large numbers) doesn't often get to these kinds of P/E /PEG levels. They pay a nice div and have the cash to increase divs and massive buybacks if they so choose. The MMs want to load up but they can't buy the size they ultimately want all at once. They need to try and get as low a price as possible and accumulate to minimze risk and ultimately, maximize gains. To do so they can enlist "analysts" that can alter earnings estimates and give newsbyte worthy "channel checks" that can be bearish if worded in certain ways (Japan 30%). Fear Uncertainty and Doubt is spread by the media shill talking heads who give their negative opinions on CNBC and those who write negative articles that cross the business wires. MMs might also say, load up on puts and push the stock down by selling short with low lot sales hitting the bid and putting out below ask offers taking the stock down levels at a time. Maybe they bought puts before doing it to profit on the downside. I theorize that they are accumulating for longer term holds when they can shake the tree of weak hands (esp on low volume) like today. Once their bellys are full of the shares of the weak handed, they can make a change and drive the stock back up, perhaps to new highs. I believe that individual investors who recognize this happening can benefit from taking advantage of the low prices. That's what I have in mind. I am accumulating post-earnings calls of various strikes and durations on big dips toward certain support levels. I typically sell on big short term spikes to take profits and reduce risk. Like the previous, week when it went to 550+ from low 500s Dec 31/Jan 2. Note, this is just an opinion, and I could be wrong. This is not advice nor is it a solicitation to buy, selll or hold AAPL or any other security. As of this writing I own AAPL call contracts. I may buy, sell or hold AAPL, or any related or unrleated security at any time, without notice.

Message.Title: Cheaper iPhone would be the beginning of the end for Apple
Message.Msg: The truth is, a race to the bottom has never been a race Apple can win, and Jobs knew it. He, unlike a lot of executives, realized that you largely created the reality you expected to find. If you released a flashier version of the same hardware everyone else was selling at a higher pricepoint, then eventually people will believe you're charging the premium because the device is worth it. If you find the next big thing, people will pay the next big price, and you can maintain the high margins that the company has traditionally needed to survive. A cheaper iPhone is the exact opposite of this kind of thinking. Worse, it's damaging to it. For all that Apple creates its own reality, consumers aren't stupid. If you have one phone at a high price and one phone at a low price, people will start to investigate the differences between the two when they make their buying decisions. And if the only thing the premium product offers is an intangiable-like build quality, a certain percent of the market will invariably choose the lower-priced phone and the margins will collapse. Worse, it hurts the mystique that lets you sell the phone at a premium in the first place. Apple needs to spend its time finding the next big product, not undermining the products it has.

Message.Title: Down nearly $189 million
Message.Msg: Yes, Tim Cook's restricted stock in Apple is down in value of nearly $189 million from this year's high. Is he worried about it? Can he not sleep? Nope, he is as happy and pleasant as ever. Think about it. Tim is in this for the long haul. His stock doesn't fully vest until 2021. What happens over a period of a few months when investors are totally irrational doesn't matter in the longer term. Tim knows all of the amazing things in Apple's pipeline. He is not worried. Tim 's net worth is down by a staggering amount in just a couple of months, but he knows that he'll gain it all back and far more. Why should Tim waste his time worrying about whiny loser investors. He needs to focus on keeping Apple at the top of the tech game. Anyone who think that Tim should worry about the stock price have it all wrong. Time will correct the stock price and I believe that it will take less time than most people imagine.

Message.Title: What is the Valuation Model For AAPL?
Message.Msg: Is it P/E, PEG, Gross Revenue Multiple, Discounted Cash Flow, or some other? AAPL seems to be valued UNIQUE as compared to virtually any other co. I can find. If the cash per share doesn't count for some reason, and you take into account there's NO debt, then its still cheaper than the S&P 500. We're talking about a bunch of boring #$%$ companies in the S&P 500 too. With no debt, the 50 billion annual cash flow pays back the current share price every 7 years or so, and the cash in bank is free & Apple brand is free as well. Unless the market is applying negative forward sales/earnings growth for a period of many quarters or even years and dismissing the cash per share I'm not seeing it, but that projection is just that, a projection if thats what it is and we'll see if that theory proves right soon enough on earnings day. I guess the deal is to stay solvent longer than the market stays irrational with respect to Apple's valuation if you're long and think the current valuation is ridiculously low. Cheers.

Message.Title: Rumors getting out of hand
Message.Msg: Some sources claimed that they have seen the sample of the low-cost iPhone, which will come with a larger display, meeting the prevailing trend for the adoption of 5-inch displays for high-end models. They added that the low-priced iPhone will also have a brand new exterior design. Here's an oxymoron if I've ever seen one: a low-cost iPhone with a larger display intended to compete with other high-end models. It's almost like DIGITIMES saw two separate rumors about low-cost iPhones and larger iPhones, threw them in a mixing bowl, and saw what came out the other end.

Message.Title: One more reason why a less expensive Iphone makes sense...
Message.Msg: 6:50 PM, Jan 09. One more reason why a cheaper iPhone could make sense: unsubsidized iPhone prices are often even steeper overseas than in the U.S. The 16GB iPhone 5 sells for $649 unlocked in the U.S. (or perhaps ~$700 after sales tax), but for $840 in China, $735 in Sweden, and a full $955 in Italy. A source tells Bloomberg Apple (AAPL) is weighing prices of $99-$149 for a low-end iPhone, while adding the device "may be smaller than current models." The ever-bullish Gene Munster imagines a $149-$199 price tag, and thinks the device could add $6.5B in annual sales. ---Silverhorseshoe

Topic.Title: Cheaper iPhone would be the beginning of the end for Apple

Message.Msg: APPL has become a very valuable brand name and APPL wants to take advantage of this brand name across all product lines. Not every one can afford a 600 dollars phone or an Apple computer,but they can afford an Ipod or a cheaper iphone to join the APPL family ,once they own an Apple product they will be more willing to learn and try other Apple products . This approach works for the automobile industry,own a Chevy and you may trade up to an Oldsmobile and finally a Cadillac or Corvette some day. It works with Mcdonald,you walk intto a McDionald outlet,you are not limited to a burger,you can try chicken,fish,spareribs,salad,milkshake,bacon and egg and any new product introduced by Mcdonald. But it does not seem to work with venerable brand names such as Coca Cola,Marlboro or Schlitz or any name brand beer,maybe lite version of the same beer, It does not work as well for cosmetics,Revlon,Max Factor or Estee Lauder or the liquor industry. I would say it works better for products which require some learning (call it investment)such as electronic goods ,automobiles,not the low end goods like toilet paper,tissus or bleach?

Message.Title: iPhone shipments should beat the analysts expectations....HERE'S WHY.....
Message.Msg: Ok, during last quarters earnings call ATT reported 4.7mil iPhone activations and Verizon had 3.1mil activations for a total of 7.8mil iPhones. Total iPhone sales were 26.9mil last quarter, so that means about 29% of sales were from ATT and Verizon. Let's take the estimates from the last two days of ATT and Verizon activations of about 13.3mil units. Taking the same percentage of total sales at 29%, that would imply roughly 46mil phones sold for the December quarter. Now here's the wildcard. iPhone 5 was released in 54 countries during December(including China and South Korea), so these countries were not part of the iPhone sales during the last quarter(September quarter). I'm projecting that should add at least another 4mil units to give a total of around 50mil total iPhones sales. Analysts consensus is 47.6mil units, so I think there's definitely some upside in the stock price after earnings. What do you guys think? Honest opinions only please.

Message.Title: upgrade woohoo!
Message.Msg: Shares of Apple Inc. were upgraded on Wednesday from a "Buy" to a "Strong Buy" by analyst Tim Jensen. The analyst told clients that Apple's fundamentals haven't changed, and that the recent decline of the stock is a compelling value. “We think AAPL will benefit from a number of recent product refreshes, including its key iPhone and iPad offerings," Mr. Jensen wrote. "We also think the new iPad Mini will contribute to share gains. We acknowledge some slip-ups and management changes of late, but see the fundamental story as intact." The analyst also told his clients that he believes Apple could use more of its $121 billion in cash for dividends and a stock buyback. Apple is currently paying a $2.65 per share dividend and is already executing a $10 billion stock buyback program. Topic.Title: Just rip the bandage off

Message.Msg: I trade my own advice, I try to get it right more times than wrong. That said, there's always room for the unexpected, but humans like to see things as opposites, yes / no, A / B, good / bad. Life is never that simple, if you're a trader then your horizon is short term, and it's a bear case for AAPL, if you're an investor, the horizon is longer, and it's a bull case. The answer as to APPL being a "good" investment, or a "buy" really depends on the context of the question. AAPL can be both a sell and a buy depending on your strategy, so it's important to understand where a sentiment is coming from. I have puts in play for the short term bear case, but I would not recommend betting against AAPL in the long run. Someone not understanding that might think I'm contradicting myself, or that the stock is doomed because I say it's going to 500, when in fact I'm quite bullish, and I'd bet my porftfolio that big money is bullish too, they'll be looking to re-enter soon. There's a strong multi year trend that's gonig to rise through 500 in about 3 months, we either reach down to touch it at the high 400's now, or it comes up to find us later, I say rip the bandage off, and let's get on with recovering. The "good" news is that the correction is almost over, at least that's how I'm going to play it with my own money. If you're in with common above this price, just hang on to them, it will come back around to pick you up.

Message.Title: wish I saw this article back in November....RE: helps explain why the stock is being held up...
Message.Msg: The first option of a new year generally has more interest than other dates and that is the case here - the huge open interest in Apple is most especially heavy in the January 19, 2013 expiring options. Most of that is call options in the $550-$800 strike range. There are hundreds of thousands: So here is our logic to being patient. It is threefold: Apple had an enormous amount of call options speculation related to its Summer surge A huge share of this was calls with a strike of around the current price of $550 and higher that expire January 19 2013 The institutional money managers that wrote those call options and bought common stock to cover will make a lot of money if a) those options expire worthless, and then b) Apple runs after that expiration date What kind of money are we talking? Let's use the more than 60,000 calls with a $600 strike price. If Apple goes to $700 before January 19, then those options have an intrinsic value of: 60,000 (call options) X 100 (shares per option) X $100 (intrinsic value per share) = $600,000,000 Six hundred million dollars not in the institutional call writers' pockets. Whereas, if Apple stays put, then runs to $700 after the expiration date, the call writers get the capital gain from the common stock they covered with, AND the entire amount for which they sold the option. And this is only one strike price we calculated - together this is billions of dollars for a two month delay in an Apple surge. Conclusion The Summer run-up Apple had correlated to a lot of call options being written, quite possibly reflecting money managers covering the calls they wrote by buying common stock, driving the share price higher.

Message.Title: PiperJaffray reiterated overweight rating and $900 price target for AAPL
Message.Msg: Munster predicts Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)’s cheaper iPhone model would have lower; screen quality, processor, and casing than its existing relatives. He also expects that it would carry a gross margin of around 30 percent, compared with 55% to 60% gross margin of a standard iPhone. In a research note, Munster wrote, “We had previously built in some expectation for a lower-priced iPhone starting in September 2013. In that quarter, we assumed about 30% of units are lower priced iPhones, which results in an ASP change from the ~$640 level we have consistently seen over the past three years to around $520. We have the cheaper iPhone contributing about $6.5 billion in revenue in 2013 or 3% of total revenue.” The research firm reiterated its overweight rating and $900 price target for AAPL.

Message.Title: Michael Shulman - sees AAPL growth in the range of 25%-27% this year
Message.Msg: The countdown to Apple’s (NASDAQ:AAPL) earnings has begun – fourteen calendar days – and the pundits are making up stuff, from bad data to false rumors, as fast as they can get their makeup up before going on television. Let’s look at the truth of the company, then the stock. I live in Washington, DC and despite that, I am no stranger to the truth. Wall Street, supposedly the arbiter of truth about companies through their stock price, is now quite delusional about Apple. The stock is selling in the mid $520s; it is worth, when compared to other stocks in the S&P 500, north of $1,200 a share. I own AAPL shares and sell AAPL puts. I am going into earnings interviewing people in Europe about the recession – see how worried I am about my position? The stock is up from $375 and change to $525 and change and people are nervous because the stock has come down from north of $700. I am not nervous. And going into the earnings announcement I suggest you look at two strategies: First, buy the stock and sell calls. Premiums are wonderful and if the stock runs, you can buy back the call and sell another one and as it runs you can do it over and over again. If the stock does not move and you sell weekly calls in AAPL you can generate a return north of 20% in a year with no underlying movement in the stock. The second option – pardon the pun – is to sell puts. Pick a stupid price – Art Cashin of UBS calls it a silly bid – and generate some cash. The geeks who run Unix workstations to trade see the short term support at $520 and long term support at $440. Sell a $520 February put and you net $2,500 in cash for the contract. That is a 4.81% return in a month, 58% on an annualized basis. Sell a February $440 put for $290 a contract, that is a return of 0.55%, 6.6% on an annualized basis. And if you own it – pick a call and collect the cash, you can always roll the call or buy the stock back. The one time I was called out I made money, the stock fell on the open the following Monday and I bought it back for less than what I was paid when I was called out.

Message.Title: IPHONE GOING TO T-MOBILE
Message.Msg: Not sure if this has been posted, but I just read that the IPhone is going to the T-Mobile network in about 3 months. This in it self is a pretty large growth area for Apple in my opinion. Plus with them releasing the iphone in a bunch of new foreign markets and the strong possibility of a deal with China Mobile, I think its going to be a pretty good year for Apple. I hope they don't release an Iphone "mini" , I'd like to see them just offer the iphone 4 with a different casing and maybe less memory as a cheaper alternative for the foreign markets. What do you guys think?

Message.Title: Capitulation
Message.Msg: I almost sold below $500 in early December and AAPL has moved sideways ever since. Early numbers from AT&T and VZ point to 62m iphones sold. The stores have been packed during weekdays and there have been very few product returns due to defects. And yet the tone of these boards has been bearish and now there's rumors about a cheaper iPhone. Folks, there are so many cool things Apple can be doing, such as multifocus camera technology. The last thing Apple needs is a cheaper phone. Let somebody else do that.

Topic.Title: AAPL trading alert

Message.Msg: I created the system myself.

Message.Title: pple's App Store is the most profitable application marketplace
Message.Msg: Apple's App Store is the most profitable application marketplace. Its closest rival, Google Play, generates only a fraction of what Apple does through app monetization. Apple generates $15 million per day in revenue from app monetization, compared to Google at $3.5 million. In 2013, I predict that Apple will continue to generate increased revenues through apps. Developers will be encouraged to create apps for Apple first, and later for Android. This will ensure that Apple continues to stay ahead of all its competitors in terms of app revenue and monetization. This is a great situation for Apple investors.
